description: This is the same species as Lepista nuda (Wood Blewit) - the name Clitocybe nuda is a synonym. Cap 5-15 cm across, convex becoming flat, lilac to purple-blue when young, fading to tan with purple tones. The surface is smooth and slightly greasy. The gills are adnate to sinuate, lilac-purple fading to tan. The stem is 4-10 cm tall, stout, purple to lilac with bulbous base. The flesh is pale purple to white with sweet floral fragrance. Pink spore print.
habitat: Found in deciduous and mixed forests, woodland edges, hedgerows, parks, gardens, and compost piles. Grows as a leaf litter decomposer in rich organic soil. Fruits scattered to gregarious in large troops or fairy rings. Prefers nitrogen-rich environments.
season: Late summer through early winter (September-December). One of the classic late-season mushrooms fruiting after frosts. Peak in late fall (October-November). In mild climates may fruit into January.
lookalikes: Cortinarius species (some deadly) - rusty brown spores and cobwebby veil
Laccaria amethystina (edible) - smaller, truly purple, thinner
Mycena pura (toxic) - smaller, fragile, radish odor
Young Cortinarius violaceus (edible) - cobwebby veil, rusty spores
safety_notes: EDIBLE: Popular edible mushroom but requires proper preparation. CRITICAL: Must be thoroughly cooked - NEVER eat raw or undercooked. Some people have allergic reactions even when cooked. Try small amounts first. Verify PINK SPORE PRINT (not rusty brown).
